With apologies in advance for the meta nature of this short thread. I get the @elonmusk is trying to make Twitter work financially. I get that he is considering a freemium approach that keeps Twitter free for all with premium access/tools for those who might need them.
What I don’t get is why he is doing this via the blue tick verification method. If free speech is important (which it is) then surely being able to trust and evaluate sources is just as important.

Why not leave the blue tick verification alone and seek a freemium model instead in which those who want to to use advanced settings (be it access to advertising tools, additional account management tools, premium access to content…) pay the $8 a month? Would that not be better?

To what extent is this correlation rather than causation? If private schools were abolished, would these jobs suddenly be less accessible to folks from leafy suburban middle class backgrounds?
The zero sum approach which suggests that in order to improve the maintained sector you need to run down the private one is logically fallacious. The former does not simply result from the latter.
If I were minded to improve the maintained sector, I would stop tilting at windmills and start investing in schools. Big time. But I guess it’s easier to place the blame elsewhere.

I think more Latin is a terrific idea. There’s no punchline. I’m serious. It’s foundational, interesting, mind-expanding, makes dozens of languages accessible and takes us out of the frame of mind that education is just preparation for employment, rather than valuable in itself.

One of the reasons for that is that Spain already opens its vaccination programme to 16-17 year olds. They're planning to open to other teenagers before school resumes in September. Mirrors approach in several other European states- UK sticking with 18+

The lack of vaccination in the rest of the world is far more important now than a few % points between European states but for those interested, Spain has now overtaken the UK on % of population fully vaccinated. Has best performance of 50 largest countries by population.

I have huge problems with these studies, where screen time is not defined (is reading a book on your tablet screen time? Is facetiming grandad? Is watching a documentary?) and which at best merely suggest unstructured screentime in lieu of structured activity is detrimental.

Which I would not dispute in the slightest. The issue for me is that studies such as this one are full of sentences like "Adolescents are also more likely [...] have their own smartphone [...] This may increase the possibility of [...] problematic social media use. Well, wow wee.

Anyway, a little while ago I wrote this piece on "screen time" and why we need studies like this to be better designed and more robust for them inform this important debate in a more reasoned manner https://josepicardo.com/education/not-all-screen-time-is-equal-some-considerations-for-schools-and-parents/…

Educational technology sceptics in the UK breathe a sigh of relief at finally finding their views represented in the political sphere.

Breaking: teaching things ‘not as easy as it looks.’ More as we get it. The misconception that ‘knowing about something’ is the same as ‘knowing how to teach it’ is at the root of a lot of nonsense. Oddly, it ignores the expert practice of ‘teaching’
So, shock horror! Academics, who don’t teach young children, are confused by the way young children are taught. Almost as if it’s a totally different skill

Great piece. Although I think the case for critical thinking relying on prior knowledge is indisputable, I also suspect students (who are usually in receiver mode) benefit from explicit opportunities to practise critical thinking, as illustrated by the exercise in first paragraph
